positive_examples: I should favor this option specifically because I might be biased against it.
Let me overcorrect to compensate for my expected bias.
I'll weight this more heavily because I suspect I underweight it.
Knowing my biases, I should go the opposite direction.
The counter-biased position is probably right just because it contradicts my intuition.
negative_examples: I'll try to assess this fairly despite potential biases.
Let me examine my reasoning for bias without overcorrecting.
Being aware of bias helps me evaluate more carefully.
I should correct for bias, but not assume the opposite is true.
Calibration means reducing bias, not inverting it.
training_hints.disambiguation: Detects overcorrection that introduces new distortions versus appropriate bias correction. Key markers: specifically because biased against, overcorrect, go opposite direction.

opposite_reasoning: Distortion is the most pragmatic choice: (1) it exists in both WordNet and SUMO, ensuring availability; (2) it captures the core semantic opposition - CounterBiasDistortionSignal corrects distortion, while Distortion represents what needs correction; (3) it has high relevance for AI safety monitoring (detecting when signals become distorted vs corrected); (4) it provides a clear conceptual axis from 'distorted/biased' to 'corrected/counter-biased'. While BiasDistortionSignal might be more precise, Distortion offers better availability and captures the essential opposition.
definition: A signal indicating overcorrection for perceived bias that introduces new distortions.
